ab.b:
XIV. Meaning of Colors, what can be signified by them.
The fourteenth Chapter.

div.ab:
1. Because the Sun shows such a strong force
that Moon, Stars and all earthly lights
must yield before its extraordinary clarity,
and because its rays resemble Gold,
and Gold is the first among metals,
we will organize our remarks
distinctly so that first, very important,
we propose that yellow represents Gold.
left-middleOn the overpowering light of the Sun.

2. Of all useful and praiseworthy colors,
we begin with yellow, the most magnificent,
since it represents the beautiful color of Gold.
Yes, Gold, which feeds the ever hungrier
senses of greedy men without satisfying them.
this brilliance from the insides of the abyss,
pulled from the belly of our Mother for us all,
has always brought much harm in the world.
left-middleThrough Gold, or for the sake of gold, many bad things have occurred.

3. For the unreasoning desire of the weak
Is already wrong, and not due to Gold.
Cadmus, the discoverer, was the first to acquire Gold.
Two Kings of Colchis took the earthâ€™s virginity,
for the sake of Gold, in the region of Samnium;
they worked to collect gold from the water
with Sheepskins, from which
the legend of the golden Fleece arose.
left-middleFrom which the legend of the Golden Fleece arose.

4. Yes, the Legend of the Argonauts, companions of Jason,
which has traveled almost the entire world.
It is stranger to read, than worthy of believing,
How, to triumph without Hercules,
they put a woman to work;
but Gold, to recount the origin of its name,
Hippocrates believed it came
from Aurora, like saffron, and glowing.
left-middleOrpheus, Valerius Flaccus, and Apollonius have written about the journey of Golden Fleece.
left-middleWhere Gold would have gotten its name

5. Or, as Isidorus says, its name is derived
from the Latin aura, which indicates
a glow of clear appearance.
Nor is Gregorius silent about
its singular gleaming quality.
And in general People always like to see,
with awakened senses, what is
pure, clear, and lustrous.

6. The clearest beauty is invisible
